content.question:
<math alttext="2 N 2 O, gas, reacts to produce 2 N 2, gas, plus O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo><mo>â†’</mo></mpadded><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mpadded></math>
The rate law for the reaction represented above is experimentally determined to be <math alttext="rate equals k times the molar concentration of N 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>rate</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mpadded><mo>]</mo></mpadded></math>. Which of the following best explains why increasing the initial concentration of <math alttext="N 2 O, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="italic">g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> at a constant temperature increases the reaction rate?

choices.label: There is a higher probability of effective molecular collisions.
The rate constant for the reaction increases.
The reaction mechanism changes to one that has a lower activation energy.

skill.text: 4.C: Explain the connection between particulate-level and macroscopic properties of a substance using models and representations.
